summary: Plant surfaces represent one of the largest habitat for bacteria and fungi where they occur in high diversities. Plant species are characterized by specific microbial communities, but the relative contributions of the plants’ phenotype, biotic and abiotic environmental conditions, and dispersal from surrounding habitats to community diversity and composition remain poorly understood. Glacier forefields – large areas of deglaciated substrate, which can be colonized by microorganisms, plants, and animals – provide an excellent opportunity to study several decades of microbial succession over the distance of only a few hundred meters. In order to evaluate the importance of the structuring factors of microbial communities, bacterial and fungal communities of the plant phyllosphere and the soil microbiome, as well as vegetation cover and arthropod communities will be recorded along a temporal gradient spanning over 170 years of microbial primary succession. Additionally, we will test hypotheses generated from field data in microcosm in the lab in order to verify correlational findings in stringent experiments and to gain novel insights into the interdependencies of microorganisms with other taxonomic groups.
title: Successions of microbes associated with below and above ground plant parts in a glacier fore field

When temperatures are falling and the first frosts end the vegetation period in the northern Alps, there is still a lot to discover in the Italian part of the mountain range. The mild-climate, a result of the influence of the Mediterranean Sea, invites for hikes until late in the season and allows nature lovers to make some interesting findings.
Caterpillar of a swallowtail, Papilio machaonOnly after a few meters we could already spot the caterpillar of a swallowtail feeding on an umbelliferous plant. Probably this little fellow will not evolve into an imago this year but will instead hibernate as a pupa and serve as the progenitor of next years swallowtail populations.
Our track lead us through the sundrenched southern slope of Monte Pizzocolo. Even though it was already late in the year, we had to start early as the south-exposed trail still becomes a very unpleasant place during the mid-day´s heat. The reflection on the water surface on the one and the heated up rocks on the other side make this part of the trail a furnace, especially during the summer months.
A pittoresque sunrise above Lake GardaGrazing goats keep the vegetation woodlessThe summit welcomes visitors with the pleasure of an amazing view on the lake and the surrounding mountains. The horizon even stretches to the glaciated peaks of the Central Alps in the backgorund. Right below the summit there is a small chapel and a small bivouac site, the Bivacco due Aceri. As the name indicates, it is located between two maple trees and invites hikers to rest and even stay over night.
View from the summit of PizzocoloThe path to the Bivacco due Aceri and the shelter. Next time we will bring a picnic with us!Up at the top we could spot a pink that was still in blossom and brought a glimpse of summer to us. We chose to descend on quite a steep trail that lead along the northern slope of the mountain. On the way back, we passed through a marvelous deciduous forest mainly consisting of sycamore maple and beech trees.
Dianthus spec. greets from the summitColchicum autumnale showing it´s dainty petalsThese forests host populations of my favorite plant, the European Cyclamen. During my undergraduate studies, I was working at the botanical garden in Augsburg. One of my jobs was to clean out the Cyclamen that were propagated there. These overbred flowers in the garden are very sensitive to mold, such as Botrytis, that infects the densely grown flower stalks and the bottom side of the leaves. During the main growing season in late summer and early autumn it was a Sisyphean challenge to keep up with removing old leaves and stalks.
Cyclamen purpurascens growing in a deciduous beech forest

Bryophyte Recording in East Styria 2019 Organized by the BLAM (Bryological and Lichenological Association for Central Europe) and the Natural History Museum Johanneum of Graz about twenty Bryologists from all German-speaking countries in Europe met in East Stryria. For four days the bryophyte-rich surroundings of the small town Miesenbach have been visited.
Group photo with eyes closed… ;-)In total we found 404 Bryophyte species in only three days! Among them some interesting records as Tetrodontium ovatum, Ulota coarctata, Cyrtomnium hymenophylloides, Kiaeria blytii and many more…

summary: : Recent research has highlighted the significance of cities for biodiversity, making them important places for conservation in their own right. Current conservation approaches in cities are mostly defensive, by focusing on remnant pockets of natural areas, or by trying to protect particular species where they occur in the built environment. These approaches are vulnerable to further urban development and do not create habitats where these do not exist anymore. An alternative strategy is to make wildlife an integral part of urban development and thereby create new habitat in the built up area. Here we address the challenge of choosing target species for such wildlife-inclusive urban design. The starting point of our conceptual framework is the regional species pool, which can be obtained from geo-referenced species data. The available habitat types on and around the development site, and dispersal barriers limit the species numbers to the local species potential. In the next step, the potential of the site for each species is analyzed – how can it be upgraded to host species given the planned development and the life-history traits of the species? For the final choice of target species, traits related to the human-animal interaction should also be considered. We suggest that stakeholders will be involved in the final species selection. Our approach differs from existing practice by 1) representing an open process where many species are potential targets of conservation, 2) the involvement of stakeholders in a participatory way.
title: A Conceptual Framework for Choosing Target Species for Wildlife-Inclusive Urban Design

summary: Based on six weeks spent in the field on six Cabo Verdean Islands in September/ October 2016 and 2017, we present 18 additions to the checklist of terrestrial biodiversity of the archipelago (ten arthropods, one bird, two fungi, and five flowering plants). Four of them are first records for Cabo Verde, the others for particular islands. Most interesting are the apple of Sodom fruit fly Dacus longistylus, perhaps actively introduced for biocontrol of the toxic apple of Sodom tree and the additions to the distribution of several bee species of the genera Amegilla, Megachile, and Xylocopa. Our observations indicate that the biodiversity of Cabo Verde is still incompletely known and more fieldwork is needed.
title: Additions to the checklist of terrestrial biodiversity of Cabo Verde

summary: Traditionally, bryophyte species were thought to have small distribution ranges and low variability. This led to the assumption that vicariance and geographic isolation play a major role in bryophyte speciation. More recently, when intraspecific morphological variation, long distance dispersal and low rates of molecular evolution in bryophytes became accepted among bryologists, a large number of locally distributed species were synonymized. As a result, many bryophyte species now show broad transcontinental geographic ranges, often with multiple disjunct distribution areas. _Epipterygium_ _tozeri_ (Bryaceae) is such a case, showing a holarctic distribution with disjunct areas in the western parts of North America, the Mediterranean and Central Asia. Collections from different geographic regions were first described as independent species, and later mostly lumped in E. tozeri based on morphology. Here, we contrast the morphological species concept in the genus _Epipterygium_ with molecular data. A combined analysis of one nuclear and two plastid loci was performed to assess species circumscriptions and distribution patterns and to reconstruct the historical biogeography in the E. tozeri complex.
title: Integrative Taxonomy reveals new Macaronesian bryohphyte species

summary: In the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, bryophyte species were seen as organisms with small distribution ranges and low variability. This led to the assumption that vicariance and geographic isolation play a major role in bryophyte speciation. Later, when intraspecific morphological variation, long distance dispersal and low rates of molecular evolution in bryophytes were accepted among bryologists, a great number of local species were synonymized. As a result, many bryophyte species now show broad transcontinental geographic ranges, often with multiple disjunct distribution areas. _Epipterygium_ _tozeri_ (Bryaceae) is such a case, showing a holarctic distribution with disjunct areas in the western parts of North America, the Mediterranean and central Asia. Specimens from different geographic regions were first described as independent species and later, many were lumped in E. _tozeri_ based on morphology. Here we contrast the morphological species concept in the genus _Epipterygium_ with molecular data. A combined analysis of one nuclear and two plastid loci was performed to assess species circumscriptions and distribution patterns and to reconstruct the historical biogeography in the _Epipterygium_ _tozeri_ complex.
title: Overlooked Diversity in Epipterygium
